awd_titl_txt: Propagation of Stochasticity in PDEs and Hybrid Inverse Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Equations with highly heterogeneous, poorly resolved, coefficients abound in applied sciences. The project proposes to analyze the influence of the statistical properties of these coefficients on the quantities of interest in many applied areas such as the uncertainty quantifications in climate predictions, the study of geological basins, and the manufacturing of composite materials. Novel methods in medical imaging often referred to as coupled-physics imaging modalities (such as Elastography or Photo-Acoustic tomography) have the potential to strongly enhance our capabilities to detect unhealthy tissues at a very early stage. The proposal will further the mathematical understanding of such problems and in close collaboration with medical physicists and bio-engineers provide robust reconstruction procedures for such modalities.

This project focuses on the theoretical and mathematical understanding of: (i) the propagation of uncertainty from heterogeneous coefficients to the solutions of differential equations; and (ii) coupled-physics inverse problems, which find applications in novel modalities in medical and geophysical imaging. The latter inverse problem aims to understand the coefficients that can or cannot be reconstructed in a given experimental environment, and the limitations in the accuracy with which such reconstructions are possible based on a given noise level. The former problem aims, among other things, to propose physics-based models for the statistical properties of the measurement noise that limit the reconstruction's accuracy of many inverse problems.

por.por_cntn:
The main thrusts of this proposal were the analysis of some inverse problems finding applications in medical and geophysical imaging and the analysis of the effects of randomness or perturbations in the asymmetric transport properties of topological insulators, which find applications in materials science as well as in geophysics.

 

In inverse problems, the main first object studied in this proposal is the so called photo-acoustic problem in a rotating setting. Photo-acoustic tomography is a novel imaging modality aiming to reconstruct the absorption properties of biological tissues in the near infra red regime. In the rotating setting, both the ultrasound detectors where measurements are acquired and the probing light source are fixed on a rotating gantry. This geometric setting prevents the application of standard inversion procedures on which the PI had worked in the past. In collaboration with Adrian Kirkeby, a graduate student from DTU who came to visit the PI at Chicago for 6 months, we showed that similar reconstructions were achieved in both the rotating and non-rotating settings. These results were obtained under the standard constraints in which microlocal analytic techniques can be applied.

A second inverse problem was analyzed in detail. It concerns the propagation of narrow beams in scattering media, for instance electromagnetic beams propagating in (thin) biological tissues or in turbulent atmospheres. The constitutive parameters modeling the underling medium were reconstructed in the setting of a Fermi pencil beam model. The main mathematical problem pertains to the justification of the Fermi pencil beam model from a general Fokker Planck equation. Beam spreading is well approximated by the Fermi pencil beam, as we show in the sense of a 1-Wasserstein distance, a natural object in this setting. `We' is the PI and postdoctoral researcher Benjamin Palacios, who was partially funded by the grant over the past two years.

Topological insulators (TI) are objects composed of two insulating half spaces characterized by different values of a topological invariant that are brought next to eachother with a joint interface that is metallic (non-insulating) and along which transport is asymmetric. TIs find applications in materials science (electronic and photonic structures) as well as geophysics (equatorial currents in the Earth atmosphere). Asymmetry here means more current going, say, from left to right than from right to left. Moreover, the topological nature of the current means that it is preserved even in the presence of even strong heterogeneities. This is a quite counter-intuitive and very different picture from what is observed in topologically trivial objects, where heterogeneities lead to scattering and hence localization (backscattering). In the above (idealized) scenario, one can communicate from one end of the interface to the other one no matter how much randomness happens to be present in between. This is the main practical appeal for such objects. The PI has analyzed the influence of randomness for some of the simplest continuous partial differential models affording such topological descriptions. The invariants take the form of indices of appropriate Fredholm operators, can be related to a quantized interface conductivity explaining the asymmetry in the current, can be computed explicitly in some cases, and can be shown to be stable with respect of large classes of random perturbations.
